title-group.div: PESI - a taxonomic backbone for Europe

div.div: This is an open access article distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License 4.0 (CC-BY), which permits unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original author and source are credited.

sec.p: Reliable taxonomy underpins communication in all of biology, not least nature conservation and sustainable use of ecosystem resources. The flexibility of taxonomic interpretations, however, presents a serious challenge for end-users of taxonomic concepts. Users need standardised and continuously harmonised taxonomic reference systems, as well as high-quality and complete taxonomic data sets, but these are generally lacking for non-specialists. The solution is in dynamic, expertly curated web-based taxonomic tools.

The Pan-European Species-directories Infrastructure (PESI) worked to solve this key issue by providing a taxonomic e-infrastructure for Europe. It strengthened the relevant social (expertise) and information (standards, data and technical) capacities of five major community networks on taxonomic indexing in Europe, which is essential for proper biodiversity assessment and monitoring activities. The key objectives of PESI were: 1) standardisation in taxonomic reference systems, 2) enhancement of the quality and completeness of taxonomic data sets and 3) creation of integrated access to taxonomic information.
This paper describes the results of PESI and its future prospects, including the involvement in major European biodiversity informatics initiatives and programs.

div.span: PESI was funded by the European Commission under the Seventh Framework Program (project reference: RI-223806), contributing to the FP7-INFRASTRUCTURES 'Capacities' sub-program under the Coordination and Support Actions (CSA) funding scheme (call: FP7-INFRASTRUCTURES-2007-2). Continuing support for the coordination and management of PESI was given by the University of Amsterdam (via the former Zoological Museum Amsterdam), and key partner institutes, including Botanischer Garten und Botanisches Museum Berlin-Dahlem (BGBM), Royal Botanical Gardnes, Kew (RBG) and Vlaams Instituut voor de Zee (VLIZ).The pan-European checklists initial set ups were established as part of the respective EC-FP4 ERMS (MAS3-CT97-0146), EC-FP5 Euro+Med (EVR1-CT-2000-40004) and EC-FP5 Fauna Europaea (EVR1-1999-20001) projects. A first pilot on integrating the pan-European checklist was carried out during the EC-FP5 EuroCAT (EVR1-CT-2002-20011) project.Preparatory work on PESI was done during the EC-FP6 EDIT (GCE 018340) and MarBEF (SUSTDEV 505446) Networks of Excellence (NoEs). Support on e-Publishing and optimising platform interoperability was given by the EC-FP7 ViBRANT (RI-261532) project and support on preparing taxonomic workflows and on installing web services was provided by the EC-FP7 BioVel (INFRA 283359) and EC-FP7 iMarine (CONNECT 283644) projects.The further development of PESI (as 'EU-Nomen') is partially covered by the EC-FP7 EU BON project (ENV 30845) and partially supported by national LifeWatch nodes, including LifeWatch Flanders and LifeWatch Greece, spin-offs of the EC-FP7 LifeWatch (INFRA 211372) project. Additional support is given by taxonomic museums or institutes, national biodiversity platforms, GBIF nodes or biodiversity agencies, hosting PESI focal points.
